SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

gr.forth.ics.swkm.model2
Class Literal

java.lang.Object
  gr.forth.ics.swkm.model2.Literal

public class Literal
extends Object

A literal value.

A literal can have one of three forms:

  • "value"
  • "value"@language
  • "value"^^type

The type of a literal must, if it exists, to be a URI. Value can be accessed with getValue(), language can be accessed with getLanguage() (and test through hasLanguage() if there is a language part), and type can be accessed with getType() (and test through hasType() if there is a language part)

Author:
Andreou Dimitris, email: jim.andreou (at) gmail (dot) com
See Also:
The specification of literals

create

public static Literal create(String value)
Creates a literal that will only have a value part. Note that the value of a literal does not include the quotes.

The textual representation of the created literal will be "value".

Parameters:
value - the value that the created literal will have
Returns:
a literal with the specified value, and null language and type parts

createWithLanguage

public static Literal createWithLanguage(String value,
                                         String lang)
Creates a literal that will have a value and a language part. Note that the value of a literal does not include the quotes.

The textual representation of the created literal will be "value"@language.

Parameters:
value - the value that the created literal will have
lang - the language that the created literal will have
Returns:
a literal with the specified value and language parts, and null type part

createWithType

public static Literal createWithType(String value,
                                     Uri type)
Creates a literal that will have a value and a type part. Note that the value of a literal does not include the quotes.

The textual representation of the created literal will be "value"^^type.

Parameters:
value - the value that the created literal will have
type - the type that the created literal will have
Returns:
a literal with the specified value and type parts, and null language part

isValid

public boolean isValid()
Returns whether this literal value is valid with regards to the validation rules (if any) of its defined type (if defined).

whether this literal value is valid with regards to the validation rules (if any) of its defined type (if defined)
